metadata.title: Metal-free catalyst for the visible-light-induced photocatalytic synthesis of quinazolinones

Metal-free catalyst for the visible-light-induced photocatalytic synthesis of quinazolinones Rongzhou Wang Investigation Visualization Writing – original draft Writing – review & editing Funding acquisition Shiyuan Liu Investigation Visualization Longfei Li Investigation Visualization Ao Song Investigation Visualization Shengsheng Yu Investigation Shuping Zhuo Visualization Ling-Bao Xing Writing – review & editing Funding acquisition ⁎ School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Shandong University of Technology, Zibo 255000, PR China School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering Shandong University of Technology Zibo 255000 PR China School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Shandong University of Technology, Zibo 255000, PR China ⁎ Corresponding author. In the present work, we have developed a novel and environmentally friendly method for the synthesis of quinazolinones using fluorescein as a photocatalyst via a condensation reaction of o-aminobenzamides and aldehydes under visible light irradiation. In this protocol, neither toxic oxidants nor transition-metal catalysts were needed, and a series of quinazolinones could be obtained in high efficiencies. In addition, this reaction can be extended to gram levels and has a large potential of wide application in future industrialization. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Visible-light-induced Photocatalysis Quinazolinones Metal-free catalyst Synthesis design 1 Introduction As a class of nitrogen-containing aromatic compounds, quinazolinones play an important role in nature and medicine, and exhibit a broad spectrum of biological and pharmaceutical properties [1], including antibacterial [2], antifungal [3], antiviral [4], antiinflammatory [5], anticonvulsant [6], antimalarial [7] and anticancer properties (Scheme 1) [8]. Although several different synthetic strategies for quinazolinones have been developed in the recent decade to meet the growing needs for screening such derivatives, the classical method is a condensation reaction between o-aminobenzamides and aldehydes to give aminal intermediates, followed by their oxidation to quinazolinones [9]. Nevertheless, these methods should be carried out with the use of excessive amounts of hazardous oxidants (KMnO4 [10], CuCl [11], 2,3-dichloro-5,6-dicyano-1,4-benzoquinone (DDQ) [12], I2 [13], and MnO2 [14]) or transition-metal catalysts with oxidants [15] under the conditions of high temperature and longer reaction times (Scheme 2a). The recent development in transition-metal-catalyzed reactions aims to develop a clean and atom economical strategy for the preparation of valuable synthetic building blocks [16]. In this regard, acceptorless dehydrogenation is one of the most attractive strategy to synthesize quinazolinones by dehydrogenative coupling of o-aminobenzamides with primary alcohols or aldehydes [17]. For example, in 2011, Zhou and his colleagues used [Cp*IrCl2]2 as a catalyst for the preparation of quinazolinones, in which hydrogen gas and H2O were generated to instead the traditional oxidation reactions (Scheme 2b) [18]. In 2015, Li and co-workers reported the synthesis of quinazolinones via a reaction between o-aminobenzamides with aldehydes using an iridium complex under reflux condition (Scheme 2b) [19]. Although these methods were very efficient, the high temperature and expensive transition-metal catalysts were still required. Recently, photocatalytic organic transformations through photo-induced electron transfer have attracted extensive attraction in both industrial and academic laboratories, since they offer many attractive superiorities such as simple experimental setup, mild reaction condition, minimal side reactions, and environmental friendliness [20]. Compared with costly and harmful UV irradiation (~6 ev), visible light (400–700 nm, ~6 ev) is much more attractive and promising in the field of organic synthesis [21]. Transition metals (e.g., iridium and ruthenium), as photocatalysts, have a wide range of applications in the organic catalytic reaction under light irradiation such as direct CH arylation, CH activation reaction, and cyclization reaction [22]. However, these complexes are expensive and potentially toxic. Therefore, developing accessible, relatively cheap, and less toxic organic photocatalysts are promising strategies to meet the increasing demand for more sustainable green chemical processes. More recently, fluorescein has been studied as an organic photocatalyst due to its visible region absorption, chemical stability, long excited-state lifetime, and favourable redox potential [23]. Although fluorescein has been widely applied in many fields such as ophthalmology, bioimaging, and biosensing because of the fluorescent properties and enhanced effects on the chemiluminescence, it was rarely applied to the organic synthetic reaction. In the present work, we reported a novel methodology of visible-light-assisted catalysis using fluorescein as a photocatalyst to prepare quinazolinones with o-aminobenzamides and aldehydes in good to excellent yields under mild reactions by irradiation of blue light (Scheme 2c). 2 Results and discussion In our initial experiment, 2-aminobenzamide (1a) and benzaldehyde (2a) were selected as the model substrates to optimize the reaction conditions under 10 W blue LEDs at room temperature (Table 1 ). Initially, in the presence of 10 mol% p-TsOH, the reaction afforded the desired product 3aa in 75% yield (Table 1, entry 1). When the amount of p-TsOH was improved, the same yield of 3aa was obtained compared to using 10 mol% p-TsOH (Table 1, entry 2). However, the lower yield was obtained when the reaction was carried out without p-TsOH (Table 1, entry 3). The influence of reaction time on the yield of the product was also studied. Under various conditions for the reaction, the optimal reaction time was 2 h (Table 1, entries 1, 4, and 5). This method was also tested by adding a dose of fluorescein, and it was found that the 2 mol% catalyst loading was found to be the best option (Table 1, entries 4, 9, and 10). Then other solvents, for instance, PhMe, THF or EtOH, were used instead of CH3CN, the yields of the desired product decreased (Table 1, entries 6–8). With these results, we decided to further explore the scope of optimum. Finally, we studied the effect of the photocatalyst and light source on the reaction and found that they were indispensable (Table 1, entries 11 and 12). Thus, the optimal catalytic conditions were 2-aminobenzamide (1a, 0.2 mmol), benzaldehyde (2a, 0.2 mmol), p-TsOH (10 mol%) and fluorescein (2 mol%) in CH3CN for 2 h under blue LEDs at room temperature. To demonstrate the applicability of this transformation, a variety of aldehydes (2) were then applied to couple with 2-aminobenzamide (1a) under the optimized reaction conditions (Table 2 ). Benzaldehydes bearing one or two electron-donating groups, such as methyl (2b and 2c), dimethyl (2d), isopropyl (2e) and methoxy (2f), were converted to the corresponding products 3ab-3af in 86–91% yields. Similarly, derivatives substituted by a halogen atom at the ortho, meta, and para positions all coupled smoothly with 1a to afford the target products (3ag-3ak) in generally good yields. Furthermore, p-hydroxybenzaldehyde (2l) was a suitable substrate, which giving the corresponding product 3al in 90% yield. When benzaldehydes with a strong electron-withdrawing group, such as cyano (2 m) and trifluoromethyl (2n), were used as substrates, the desired products 3am and 3an could be obtained in 91% and 86% yields, respectively. Interestingly, 2-pyridinecarboxaldehyde (2o) and 2-thenaldehyde (2p) were converted to corresponding products in 83% (3ao) and 86% (3ap) yields. Besides, 1-naphthaldehyde (2q) was also proved to be a good substrate, giving the product (3aq) in 88% yield. When phenylpropyl aldehyde (2r) was tested, the corresponding product 3ar was obtained in 86% yield. Notably, unsaturated aldehydes (2s and 2t) also smoothly coupled with 1a to afford the corresponding products 3as and 3at in good yields and the olefinic C=C bond survived under the optimized reaction conditions as well. It is important to note that various aliphatic aldehydes (2u-2w), including linear and cyclic aliphatic aldehydes, were tolerated, giving 83–86% yields of the corresponding quinazolinones. To our delight, formaldehyde (2x), as the simplest aldehyde, was also proved to be a suitable substrate, furnishing 4-hydroxyquinazoline (3ax) in 82% yield, which is an important intermediate of an anticancer drug Erlotinib. To further expand the scope of the reaction, transformations with respect to o-aminobenzamides (1) were then studied. As shown in Table 3 , electron-donating and -withdrawing substituents (-CH3, -F, -Cl, and -Br) on the phenyl group of o-aminobenzamides have a minor effect, affording corresponding quinazolinones in 80–90% yields. In addition, it was worth noting that 2-amino-N-methylbenzamide (1f) and 2-amino-N-phenylbenzamide (1g) were also tolerated, and the target product 3fa and 3ga were obtained in 87% and 89% yields, respectively. In order to test the utility of this photochemical strategy, a 6 mmol scale-up reaction was conducted (Scheme 3a). The reaction of 2-aminobenzamide (1a) and benzaldehyde (2a) were also performed very well under blue LEDs in a smaller amount of solvent, giving the product 3aa in 78% yield (1.04 g), which might be a green and significant potential photochemical protocol with a wide range of applications in industry. Furthermore, the present photocatalytic system was also successfully applied to the synthesis of a truncated version of an anticancer drug Erlotinib. The total yield of N-(3-ethynylphenyl)quinazolin-4-amine (5) reached 59 % through a two-step synthesis process (Scheme 3b). To gain mechanistic insight into this transformation, a series of control experiments were performed, and the results were summarized in Scheme 4. In the first step, cyclic intermediate 2,3-dihydro-2-phenylquinazoline-4(1H)-one (4) were obtained in high yield (>99%) in the presence of p-TsOH after 30 min. Then, the product 3aa was formed in 91% yield under blue LEDs after another 2 h (Scheme 4a), which was similar to the result in one-pot (Table 1, entry 4). However, using the same reaction method, intermediate 4 and product 3aa were obtained in low yields without p-TsOH (Scheme 4b). The observations suggested that p-TsOH played an important role in the cyclization step. In addition, we investigated the reaction of intermediate 4 as the initial material to synthesize the target compound, and the desired product 3aa was synthesized in 92% yield under the optimized reaction conditions (Scheme 4c). Next, we conducted the oxidation reaction of intermediate 4 in the absence of fluorescein or blue light source, which indicated that they were all essential for this reaction (Scheme 4d and 4e). To identify the function of molecular oxygen in the reaction, 5,5-dimethyl-1-pyrroline-N-oxide (DMPO) was added to a mixture of 4, fluorescein, and CH3CN upon irradiation by blue LEDs. The typical signal of the adduct of O2 •- with DMPO was immediately observed (Fig. 1 a). When 2,2,6,6-tetramethylpiperidine (TEMP) was used as the singlet oxygen (1O2) scavenger in the same solution, no signal was detected (Fig. 1b). In addition, the product was obtained in 48% yield in the presence of radical scavenger TEMPO (2,2,6,6-tetramethyl-1-piperidinyloxy) under standard conditions (Scheme 5 ). Therefore, we believed that superoxide radical anion (O2 •−) generated from molecular oxygen was the active species of the reaction. Based on the above results and literature reports [24], a possible mechanism for the photochemical oxidative cyclization of 2-aminobenzamide (1a) and benzaldehyde (2a) by a visible assisted catalysis was proposed in Scheme 6 . Initially, intermediate A was formed by the condensation between 1a and 2a in the presence of p-TsOH. Subsequently, the cyclization of A occurred to produce the cyclized compound 4 with the deprotonation, which was converted to intermediate B with the action of fluorescein* (Fl*) produced by fluorescein (Fl) under the visible light conditions. Accompanied by the oxidation fluorescein*− (Fl*−) under O2 in the air, fluorescein was generated and the anion radical (O2 •−) was released. The reaction of the resulting intermediate B with the anion radical (O2 •−) afforded the intermediate C and hydroperoxyl radical (HO2 •). At last, the desired product 3aa was obtained by deprotonation of intermediate C, while H2O2 was also generated from hydroperoxyl radical (HO2 •). 3 Conclusions In summary, we have developed a photocatalyzed direct synthesis of quinazolinones from o-aminobenzamides with aldehydes under a visible-light-induced condensation using fluorescein as a photocatalyst. This synthetically valuable procedure exhibits good functional group tolerance and a variety of quinazolinones are obtained in good to excellent yields. Moreover, the method provides one of the most environmentally benign catalytic routes to quinazolinones by avoiding using oxidants or metals. Importantly, the gram-scale experiment has been successfully conducted, which might indicate that this strategy has more applications in the future. 4 Experimental General information. Melting points were measured on a RY-1 micro-melting apparatus. Proton nuclear magnetic resonance (1H NMR) spectra were recorded at 400 MHz using a 400 spectrometer. Chemical shifts are reported in delta (δ) units, parts per million (ppm) downfield from tetramethylsilane or ppm relative to the center of the singlet at 2.50 ppm for DMSO‑d 6. Coupling constant J values are reported in hertz (Hz), and the splitting patterns were designated as follows: s, singlet; d, doublet; t, triplet; m, multiplet; b, broad. Carbon-13 nuclear magnetic resonance (13C NMR) spectra were recorded at 100 MHz using a 400 spectrometer. Chemical shifts are reported in delta (δ) units, ppm relative to the center of the triplet at 39.5 ppm for DMSO‑d 6. 13C NMR spectra were routinely run with broadband decoupling. Analytical thin-layer chromatography (TLC) was carried out using 0.2-mm commercial silica gel plates. General procedure for the synthesis of quinazolinones. To an oven-dried 15 mL flat quartz glass jar with a magnetic stirrer were added o-aminobenzamides (1, 0.2 mmol), aldehydes (2, 0.2 mmol), fluorescein (2 mol%), p-TsOH (10 mol%) and CH3CN (2 mL). The open-air reaction container was placed under 10 W blue LEDs lamp at room temperature for 2 h. After completion of the reaction, the reaction mixture was concentrated in vacuo and purified by flash column chromatography with hexane/ethyl acetate to afford the corresponding products. Procedure for gram-scale synthesis of 3aa. 1a (816 mg, 6 mmol), 2a (636 mg, 6 mmol), fluorescein (40 mg, 2 mol%), p-TsOH (103 mg, 10 mol%) and CH3CN (10 mL) were added into a 25 ml flat quartz glass jar with a stirrer under 10 W blue LEDs lamp at room temperature for 2 h. After completion, the mixture was concentrated in vacuo and purified by flash column chromatography with hexanes/ethyl acetate to afford the product 3aa (1.04 g, 78%). Procedure for the synthesis of N-(ethynylphenyl)quinazolin-4-amine (5). The intermediate Quinazolin-4(3H)-one (3ax) was prepared from the consadition reaction of the 2-aminobenzamide (1a) and formaldehyde (2x) under the optimized reaction conditions. 3ax (150 mg, 1.0 mmol), 3-aminophenylacetylene (140 mg, 1.5 mmol), BOP (575 mg, 1.3 mmol), DMF (2 mL) was placed in an oven-dried 25 mL reactin tube charged with a stir bar. Then, DBU (230 mg, 1.5 mmol) was added drop-wise. The reaction mixture was heated at 110 °C in an oil bath for 12 h. After completion of the reaction, the mixture was then cooled to ambient temperature and 20 mL H2O was added. The mixture was extracted with ethyl acetate (20 mL × 3), and the ethyl acetate layers were combined, dried with anhydrous sodium sulfate, filtered, and concentrated by evaporation under reduced pressure. The crude product was isolated and purified by filtering a hexanes/ethyl acetate (5:1) solution through a pad of silica gel. Then the solvent was removed under reduced pressure to afford the desired product 5 (177 mg, 72%). CRediT authorship contribution statement Rongzhou Wang: Investigation, Visualization, Writing – original draft, Writing – review & editing, Funding acquisition. Shiyuan Liu: Investigation, Visualization. Longfei Li: Investigation, Visualization. Ao Song: Investigation, Visualization. Shengsheng Yu: Investigation. Shuping Zhuo: Visualization. Ling-Bao Xing: Writing – review & editing, Funding acquisition. Declaration of Competing Interest The authors declare that they have no known competing financial interests or personal relationships that could have appeared to influence the work reported in this paper. Acknowledgment We are grateful for the financial support from the National Natural Science Foundation of China (22005179), and Natural Science Foundation of Shandong Province (ZR2020QB113 and ZR2020MB018). Supplementary materials Supplementary material associated with this article can be found, in the online version, at doi:10.1016/j.mcat.2021.111668. coredata.dc:description: In the present work, we have developed a novel and environmentally friendly method for the synthesis of quinazolinones using fluorescein as a photocatalyst via a condensation reaction of o-aminobenzamides and aldehydes under visible light irradiation. In this protocol, neither toxic oxidants nor transition-metal catalysts were needed, and a series of quinazolinones could be obtained in high efficiencies. In addition, this reaction can be extended to gram levels and has a large potential of wide application in future industrialization.
coredata.dc:title: Metal-free catalyst for the visible-light-induced photocatalytic synthesis of quinazolinones
